stay constant.

but remains ahead of the upper shock wave.
to the location of the upper shock wave, then remains static.
directly beneath the upper shock wave and at the same rate.

variant.question: A shock wave on a lift generating wing will:

options.text: move aft as Mach number is increased.
move slightly forward in front of a downward deflecting aileron.
be situated at the greatest wing thickness when the aeroplane reaches the speed of sound.
reach its highest strength when flying at the critical Mach number.

variant.question: A shock wave on a lift generating wing will:

options.text: move forward as Mach number is decreased.
be situated at the greatest wing thickness when the aeroplane reaches the speed of sound.
reach its highest strength when flying at the critical Mach number.
move slightly forward in front of a downward deflecting aileron.

variant.question: A shock wave on a lift generating wing will:

options.text: move slightly forward in front of a upward deflecting aileron.
reach its highest strength when flying at the critical Mach number.
be situated at the greatest wing thickness when the aeroplane reaches the speed of sound.
move forward as Mach number is increased.

variant.question: A shock wave on a lift generating wing will:

options.text: Move slightly aft in front of a downward deflecting aileron.
Be situated at the greatest wing thickness when the aeroplane reaches the speed of sound.
Move forward as Mach number is increased.
Reach its highest strength when flying at the critical Mach number.

variant.question: To increase the critical Mach number of a conventional aerofoil section:

options.text: its thickness to chord ratio should be reduced.
its leading edge radius should be increased.
its camber should be increased.
it should be flown at higher angles of attack.

variant.question: Compared with an oblique shock wave a normal shock wave has a

options.text: higher loss in total pressure.
higher total temperature.
lower static temperature.
higher total pressure.

variant.question: What is the effect of aeroplane mass on shock wave intensity at constant Mach number?

options.text: Increasing mass increases shock wave intensity.
A change in mass does not influence shock wave intensity.
Decreasing mass increases shock wave intensity.
Decreasing mass increases shock wave intensity at below standard temperatures.

variant.question: In case of supersonic flow retarded by a normal shock wave, a high efficiency (low loss in total pressure) can be obtained, if the Mach number in front of the shock wave is:

options.text: small but still supersonic.
lower than 1.
exactly 1.
high (supersonic).

variant.question: If a shock wave appears on the upper side of a wing or blade element, what will happen to the centre of pressure?

options.text: It will move towards the trailing edge.
It will move towards a random direction.
It will not move.
It will move towards the leading edge.

variant.question: As the Mach number increases in straight and level flight, a shock wave on the upper surface of the wing will:

options.text: move towards the trailing edge.
disappear.
move towards the leading edge.
not move.

variant.question: What is the impact of a change in Angle of Attack (AoA) on a normal shock wave at a constant Mach number?

options.text: The intensity of the shock wave increases as AoA increases.
The location of the shock wave moves rearwards on the wing.
The location of the shock wave moves forwards on the wing.
The intensity of the shock wave decreases as AoA increases.

variant.question: A shockwave is formed both on the upper and lower surface of the wing. Mach number is increased. Where is the lower surface shock wave in relation to the upper surface?

options.text: More forward.
Impossible to say.
More aft.
At the same position.

variant.question: Air passes through a normal shock wave. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: The static temperature increases.
The static temperature decreases.
The static pressure decreases.
The velocity increases.

 II The total pressure in front of an oblique shock wave is higher than behind it.

variant.question: The loss of total pressure in a shock wave is due to the fact that:

options.text: kinetic energy in the flow is changed into heat energy.
the speed reduction is too high.
the friction in the boundary layer is higher.
the static pressure decrease is comparatively high.

variant.question: Airflow passing through a normal shockwave will show the following changes of I. Speed, II. Pressure and III Temperature respectively:

I. up,       II. up,       III. down

variant.question: When the Mach number is slowly increased in straight and level flight the first shock waves will occur:

options.text: on the upper surface at the wing root.
somewhere on the fin.
somewhere on the horizontal tail.

options.text: On the upper wing, where it is thickest.
Somewhere on the horizontal tail.
On the upper wing, close to the leading edge

variant.question: What happens to the strength, the length, and the location of a normal shock wave when the Mach number (M) is increasing at positive lift?  The strength of the shock wave

options.text: increases, its length increases, and the shock wave moves downstream.
increases, its length increases, and the shock wave moves upstream.
decreases, its length decreases, and the shock wave moves upstream.
decreases, its length decreases, and the shock wave moves downstream.

variant.question: How will the density and static temperature change in a supersonic flow from a position in front of a shock wave to behind it?

options.text: Density will increase, static temperature will increase.
Density will increase, static temperature will decrease.
Density will decrease, static temperature will increase.
Density will decrease, static temperature will decrease.

variant.question: How will the density and static temperature change in a supersonic flow from a position in front of a shock wave to behind it?

options.text: Density will increase, temperature will increase.
Density will increase, temperature will decrease.
Density will decrease, temperature will increase.
Density will decrease, temperature will decrease.

faster than that in front of the shock wave,but supersonic.

faster than that in front of the shock wave, but subsonic.

the reduction in the local speed of sound from in front of the shock wave to behind it increases.
the coefficient of drag increases and the coefficient of lift decreases.
